statement.text: Retrograde access involves puncturing a distal vessel (tibial or pedal artery) to approach a lesion from below, often used when antegrade crossing fails or when bidirectional approach (SAFARI technique) improves CTO crossing success.

explanation.intuition: When you can't get through a blockage going forward, sometimes coming at it from behind works better. Retrograde access lets you approach the 'back door' of a chronic total occlusion, often finding a softer entry point.
explanation.key_insight: The distal cap of CTOs is often softer than the proximal cap because of less organized thrombus and fibrous tissue. Retrograde approach exploits this asymmetry. SAFARI (Subintimal Arterial Flossing with Antegrade-Retrograde Intervention) uses bidirectional wiring to maximize success.
explanation.technical_details: Access sites: anterior tibial (best for SFA CTOs), posterior tibial, dorsalis pedis. Technique: ultrasound-guided micropuncture (21G), 4F sheath, 0.014-0.018 inch CTO wire. SAFARI: antegrade and retrograde wires meet in subintimal space, externalize one wire through other access, deliver devices. Success rates for retrograde: 70-90% after failed antegrade. Complications: access site hematoma, dissection, vessel spasm.

clinical_features.SAFARI: Subintimal Arterial Flossing with Antegrade-Retrograde Intervention

clinical_pearls: Anterior tibial is preferred access for SFA CTOs
Always use ultrasound guidance for tibial/pedal puncture
Consider early conversion to retrograde rather than prolonged antegrade attempts
